message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen suggest a possible diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. The sweat test is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis and should be performed next to confirm the diagnosis. Mutation analysis and measurement of fecal elastase levels may also be used in the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, but the sweat test is the most reliable. Nasal potential difference may be used in research settings but is not routinely used in clinical practice.

The next step would be to perform a sweat test, which is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis. Mutation analysis and measurement of fecal elastase levels can also be used to diagnose cystic fibrosis, but sweat test is the initial test. Nasal potential difference can be used to confirm or rule out cystic fibrosis, but it is not an initial diagnostic test.

Elevated levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen is a marker for cystic fibrosis, and the next step in evaluating the newborn for cystic fibrosis is a sweat test, which measures the amount of chloride in sweat. Mutation analysis can confirm a diagnosis but is not the next step in evaluation. Measurement of fecal elastase levels is used to evaluate pancreatic function in cystic fibrosis, and nasal potential difference is a research tool used in the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.

Mutation analysis is used to confirm a diagnosis when the sweat test is inconclusive or unavailable. Measurement of fecal elastase levels is used to evaluate pancreatic function, which can be affected in cystic fibrosis, but it is not a diagnostic test. Nasal potential difference testing is used in research and clinical settings to evaluate the effects of mutations on chloride transport, but it is not routinely used for diagnosis.

The most common and definitive test for cystic fibrosis is a sweat test, which can help detect abnormal levels of chloride in sweat. Mutation analysis may also be performed, but a sweat test is usually done first. Measurement of fecal elastase levels is used to evaluate pancreatic function in patients with cystic fibrosis, but it does not confirm the diagnosis. Nasal potential difference is a research tool used in cystic fibrosis diagnosis and management, but it is not part of routine clinical practice.

Among the options, a sweat test is the most appropriate initial test for confirming the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Mutation analysis may be used to confirm the diagnosis if the sweat test is positive, while measurement of fecal elastase levels and nasal potential difference may be used as adjunct tests.
